review.title: Co-clustering of Fuzzy Lagged Data
review.abstract: The paper focuses on mining patterns that are characterized by a fuzzy lagged relationship between the data objects forming them. Such a regulatory mechanism is quite common in real life settings. It appears in a variety of fields: finance, gene expression, neuroscience, crowds and collective movements are but a limited list of examples. Mining such patterns not only helps in understanding the relationship between objects in the domain, but assists in forecasting their future behavior. For most interesting variants of this problem, finding an optimal fuzzy lagged co-cluster is an NP-complete problem. We thus present a polynomial-time Monte-Carlo approximation algorithm for mining fuzzy lagged co-clusters. We prove that for any data matrix, the algorithm mines a fuzzy lagged co-cluster with fixed probability, which encompasses the optimal fuzzy lagged co-cluster by a maximum 2 ratio columns overhead and completely no rows overhead. Moreover, the algorithm handles noise, anti-correlations, missing values and overlapping patterns. The algorithm was extensively evaluated using both artificial and real datasets. The results not only corroborate the ability of the algorithm to efficiently mine relevant and accurate fuzzy lagged co-clusters, but also illustrate the importance of including the fuzziness in the lagged-pattern model.
histories: Under consideration for publication in Knowledge and Information Systems
Under consideration for publication in Knowledge and Information Systems. The final publication is available at Springer viathis http URL
review.COMMENTS: Under consideration for publication in Knowledge and Information Systems

metadata.title: Co-clustering of Fuzzy Lagged Data

sections.text: Keywords: fuzzy delayed clustering of data; spatio-temporal patterns; time delay; biclustering; data mining

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: In fact, it is a way in which people are able to determine for themselves what they want and what they want.

sections.heading: 2. Model
sections.text: A downstream co-cluster of a real number matrix is a tuple (I, T, J) representing a submatrix defined by a subset of columns J over a subset of rows I with their respective column numbers. (See example in Figure 2d) The downstream co-cluster model is a tuple (I, T, F) in which J is a subset of columns, I is a subset of rows with their corresponding lags T, aligned to some fuzzy co-clusters of a real number X is a tuple (I, J, F) in which J is a subset of columns, I is a subset of corresponding lags T pointing to some fuzzy mechanisms of F (see example in Fig. 2e).

sections.heading: 2.1. Hardness Results
sections.text: The complexity of the fuzzy-lagged co-clustering problem depends on the nature of the cluster being degraded, which is reflected in the objective function µ used. Previous literature has shown that many such non-fuzzy and non-lagged instances are NP-complete [17, 49, 60, 70].Observation 1. Any hardness or inapproximation resulting from either the non-fuzzy or non-lagged problem implies the same result for the fuzzy-lagged problem (Ti = 0, 60, 70].The fuzzy-lagged co-clustering problem extends to the lagged co-clustering problem (fi, j = 0, I, J), which in turn extends the co-clustering problem (Ti = 0, I).Thus, any valid instance of the non-fuzzy-clustering problem or the non-lagged problem can be regarded as an instance of the fuzzy-lagged problem.

sections.heading: 3. The FLC Algorithm
sections.text: We now present the FLC algorithm. This section also contains proof of the algorithm's guarantee of a fixed probability of degrading a fuzzy delayed co-cluster, which includes an optimal fuzzy-delayed co-cluster, in a polynomic number of iterations. In addition, we provide a runtime analysis and several enhancements.

sections.heading: 3.1. The Algorithm
sections.text: The input of the algorithms is: a matrix A of the real numbers; a maximum allowed error w; a maximum allowed fuzziness degree F; a minimum fraction of the rows β; and, a minimum fraction of the columns γ. The algorithm itself uses a projected cluster approach. This common technique for mining co-clusters [49, 65] uses iterative random projections that unite with the specified β, F, and the optimal fuzzy-lagged co-clusters. Each mined cluster achieves exactly the rows and delays of the optimal clusters, with a maximum ratio of its columns (i.e., a maximum addition of the J columns) and a maximum ratio of its error.Algorithm 1 represents the FLC algorithms.

sections.heading: 3.2. Run-time
sections.text: The line addition phase (lines 8-12) treats a sliding window for O (n · | S | · F) events for each of the m lines. Therefore, its runtime for each of the n columns is O (m · n | S | F · log (n · S | F))). Therefore, its runtime is O (n · mF · log (mF)). Thus, the inner runtime for the loops is: O (mn log (mn) log (n) F).The total number of iterations is limited by theorem 2 to N = O (1 / βγ | S |). sections.heading: 3.3. Sub-optimality of FLC Algorithm
sections.text: Next, we will analyze the ability of the FLC algorithm to mine a limited and relevant number of co-clusters. (1) Specifically, we will prove that the algorithm guarantees that it will come to me, with a fixed probability, in a polynomial number of iterations. (1) Consequently, the mined cluster will have a maximum ratio of 2 co-clusters that includes an optimal cluster error. We demonstrate this guarantee with experiments on both artificial and real datasets in Section 4. Since the FLC algorithm deeply inspires the non-fuzzy stored co-cluster algorithms [70], its capabilities and theoretical analysis, the structure of the evidence is based on an important finding that a sufficient size is sufficient for a discriminatory co-cluster algorithm.

sections.heading: 3.4. Extensions
sections.text: Next, we present several extensions of the FLC algorithm and the resulting algorithmic modifications that support these extensions.

sections.heading: 3.4.1. Varying Fuzziness
sections.text: An essential feature of the FLC algorithm is the maximum allowed blur F. This blur is assumed for all entries in the matrix, and the algorithm can be extended to include a different maximum blur for each line of the matrix, which is called Fi, i. To achieve this, the algorithm must be modified in events that are later used by the slider window (lines 9 and 16 of algorithm 1). Essentially, the modification is to use the maximum allowed blur of line Fi instead of the global blur F. The changes are as follows: line 9, which collects lines, should be changed to: Push a 4w-wide window to {es, j, f | it, j = Ai, j + f − Ap, s, j − Ap, j − f, s − f, s − f, s, and the maximum number of allowed lines. Line 16, which collects columns, should be modified so that window {es, i, f, i, i, i, i, i, i, i, i, i, i, and the maximum number of allowed lines, it should be changed to Aj, f, f, f, f, f, f, f.

sections.heading: 3.4.2. Reduction in Size of the Discriminating Set
sections.text: The discriminatory set S, as shown by theorem 1, is a small subset of size O (log (mn) | IV. Nevertheless, the number of iterations N required to achieve the probable guarantee shown by theorem 2 is exponentially proportional to | S |. To improve the runtime of the algorithm, we propose to take a subset of discriminatory columns S, called S0, and assume that it has zero blur across all rows in the cluster, i.e., let (I, T, J, F) be a blurry co-cluster with a discriminatory set of columns S, assuming that fi, j = 0, is blurred for all i, j, j, S0. The assumption reduces the combinatory number of rows that must be filtered out by the discriminating set, thus reducing the size required for the task (line 4 of the algorithm 1) of blur required set.

sections.heading: 4. Experiments
sections.text: Next, we present a comprehensive evaluation of the FLC algorithm that uses both artificial and real data.

sections.heading: 4.2. Experiments with Flight of Pigeon Flocks
sections.text: In a second set of experiments, we examined the ability of the FLC algorithm to remove clusters from real life.

sections.heading: 4.2.1. Mixed Datasets: Homing Flight and Free Flight
sections.text: The aim of the experiment is to test the error and fuzziness effects on the precision and retrieval of the mining clusters.

metadata.abstractText: The paper focuses on mining patterns that are characterized by a fuzzy lagged relationship between the data objects forming them. Such a regulatory mechanism is quite common in real-life settings. It appears in a variety of fields: finance, gene expression, neuroscience, crowds and collective movements, are but a limited list of examples. Mining such patterns not only helps in understanding the relationship between objects in the domain, but assists in forecasting their future behavior. For most interesting variants of this problem, finding an optimal fuzzy lagged co-cluster is an NP-complete problem. We present a polynomial-time Monte-Carlo approximation algorithm for mining fuzzy lagged co-clusters. We prove that for any data matrix, the algorithm mines a fuzzy lagged co-cluster with fixed probability, which encompasses the optimal fuzzy lagged co-cluster by a maximum 2 ratio columns overhead and completely no rows overhead. Moreover, the algorithm handles noise, anti-correlations, missing values and overlapping patterns. The algorithm was extensively evaluated using both artificial and real-life datasets. The results not only corroborate the ability of the algorithm to efficiently mine relevant and accurate fuzzy lagged co-clusters, but also illustrate the importance of including fuzziness in the lagged-pattern model.
